author: JohnnyTheOne

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with MG Chemicals Wood filament. Some clean-up required on my print. Stringing of the wood filament and the large nozzle size made reproduction of the braille dots immensely difficult.

description.text: Following up on the Fittle Fish I decided to create blocks for a different animal for the #RemixChallenge.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.0875mm Layer Height , 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Printed with MG Chemicals Wood filament. Some clean-up required on my print. Stringing of the wood filament and the large nozzle size made reproduction of the braille dots immensely difficult.

Researching braille spacing and character set.

I consulted the Accessible and Usable Buildings and Facilities Standard (2003, ICC/ANSI A117.1) which gave some ranges for the size and spacing of braille dots. Deviating from their guidelines, I used Grade 1 lettering as this is intended as an educational toy for children.

The standard called for the following dimensions:
Dot base diameter: 1.5-1.6mm
Distance between two dots of the same cell: 2.3-2.4mm
Dot height: 0.6mm-0.9mm
Domed or round shape for the dots.

I went with the largest option for each dimension as this range of sizes can be difficult for hobbyist level FDM printers (like I own).

Dog Shape

The dog outline created as just a quick sketch on a notepad. Later I was able to import a photo of the sketch into the design to aid in the creating of the digital sketch.

Dog outline sketch Fittle Fish Design elements

In addition to the basic concept of multi-part braille "puzzle", I also incorporated a few specific design elements from the original Fittle Fish.

  • Different shaped pegs on each piece. This prevents the D block from attaching to the G block.
  • Recessed groove to denote the orientation of the braille lettering.
  • Basic noun at a similar grade level
  • "Flat" object. Fittle's other designs incorporate more 3-dimensionality. I feel like this works well if the braille is on the same plane (the train design), but isn't great when the braille shifts around (the car design)
Dimensioning the Braille dots

A laser cut rope/string making machine. It is designed to attach onto a drill to make fine twisted ropes or string. In addition to the laser cut parts you will need 4 screw in hooks, an M6 bolt and two nuts from the hardware store.

Cut the laser cut parts out of 3mm plywood or bamboo. Glue the 8 large gear pieces together in pairs, one with a hole one without, to make the 4 outer gears. Glue the two smaller gear pieces together to make the central gear. Glue the two frame pieces together (this is just to make thicker and give greater strength). Push a a screw in hook through each of the 4 holes in the base and screw into the hole in the outer gear on the otherside. Push the bolt through the central hole (from the side with the hooks on it). Place the central gear over the bolt and do up the nuts. The first nut should pull down into the inset in the central gear so that when the nut is turned the gear also turns. Screw the second nut down over the first - this provides something for your drill to grip on. Get a nut/wrench attachment for you powerdrill. Place it over the central gear and gently run it until the gears turn smoothly. Now your machine is ready to make rope. See for example: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NUHN3q6k24s

comments.text:
This is a great tool !!
I want to build similar tool to untwist useless CAT5 wires to make single strand copper wire.
I have an idea but do not have the mechanical and computer skill to do the parts:
The tool will have a main rotating axis driven by a electric drill.
Two wire holder rolls will be used to collect the untwisted CAT5 wires.
The wire holder rolls rotation axis will be perpendicular to the main axis, one on each side.
Each wire holder roll rotation is engaged to the main axis rotation via a 90 degree gear.
The gear will engage and dis-engage based on the tension of the twisted wire via a spring - it will dis-engage if the tension is too high.
I wish someone can make this and I will build one for my use. Overall I think only a few parts need to build built for this simple tool.

We designed this castle playset as a concept for demonstrating toy manufacturing at home using a 3D printer.

The set contains walls, towers, houses, characters, animals, and a myriad of different props. All parts are small enough to be 3D-printed in a build volume of 140 x 140 x140 mm.

The walls and towers fit together easily using a simple 3D-printable butterfly joint. You can make as many parts as you want to create your original castle layout!

Note: Please let us know if you have any suggestions for new objects in this kit. We will continue to expand this collection.

This project was created by Tim Wahlström in cooperation with the 3D-team at CreativeTools.se in Sweden.

VIDEO

  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6yjV6TtttiA

. #3DCastlePlayset

By Creative Tools

Home - Youtube - Things - #3DBenchy - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Instructables - Instagram - Pinterest - Flickr - LinkedIn

Notes:

We recommend using typical settings of FFF 3D printers as described below:

  • Layer thickness: 0.2 mm (200 microns)
  • Perimeters (shells): 2
  • Infill: 15%
  • Top solid layers: 4
  • Bottom solid layers: 3

comments.text: Watch the video again.  At 2:36 you can see that they use a spring from a click pen.  Put the spring on the plunger shaft.  Glue the plunger head on.  Thread the shaft through the rear hole of the cannon and then glue the pull knob onto the shaft.  Now when you pull the plunger back and let go, the pen spring will snap it back into place

title: Laser Engraved Infographics for Aquaponics Teaching

description.text:
The "Aquaponics infographics" is a educational series to make the understanding of the technique easier and intuitive. Every infographic has two versions:

  • The Colourful one with extended information [ For a selection of high quality photos check: https://goo.gl/XEjkhn ]

  • The Black and White for laser engraving at your local Fab Lab [There are more than 1000 locations spread by over 78 countries]

In our blogs there is extra info about the infographics: http://aquaponicslab.org/blog/

Files Included:

  • PDF file - Ready for laser cutting [With hand cut outs for easy holding]
  • SVG file - For Editing [Please leave AquaponicsLab.org logo and the disclaimer]
  • Colour Images for Normal Printing [Check our blog for more options: https://goo.gl/XEjkhn]

--------------------Laser cutting Guidelines [For Epilog 40w mini]--------------------------------------

Material Choice for best results:

  • Type: Plywood [High Sap Content Preferred]
  • Thickness: 3mm

Video on how to set up: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hyBCxz3jGlk

Option A: Raster Settings [Low Quality]:

  • Time: 40 mins
  • Speed: 50%
  • Power: 100%
  • Dithering: Brighten
  • DPI: 400

Option B: Raster Settings [Good Quality]

  • Time: 1 hour and 5 mins
  • Speed: 60%
  • Power: 100%
  • Dithering: Brighten
  • DPI: 600

Option C: Raster Settings [Best Quality]:

  • Time: 1 hour 40 mins
  • Speed: 80%
  • Power: 100%
  • Dithering: Brighten
  • DPI: 1200

Vector Cutting (Equal for option A, B and C):

  • Speed: 14%
  • Power: 100%
  • Frequency: 500 Hz
  • DPI: 600

Laser Cutter Used:

Brand: Epilog
Model: Laser mini
Power: 40w
Bed Size: 600 x 300 mm

Licensing Info:
2016 by AquaponicsLab.org
Other than organisational logos/brands/trademarks, all content on this document is
licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International license.
Infographic to learn about Aquaponics
This material can be use as part of a lesson plan.

This mold will allow you to create edible cases for your iPhone.
Haven't you always wanted to carry your phone in a case made out of chocolate cake in case you get hungry? or drop it to only see it bounce harmlessly on the ground because it's in a jello case? This mold will help you get started on the path to making your own culinary iPhone cases.

• Print mold.

  • Prepare food and pour it into mold.

  • Refrigerate, bake, or cure until food is ready to be taken out of the mold.

  • Remove from mold and insert phone into edible case.
    • Warning: make sure whatever you are making the mold out of is safe for cooking. We don't want any melting molds starting fires.

description.text: An easy to build, cheap, vacuum former.

Cut out one of each svg OR dxf file on a laser cutter or CNC out of 1/4" plywood or mdf (actual thickness should be 0.2-0.208).  
3d print (1) hose_adapter.stl, (4) post_holder.stl  
Fit the frame pieces together, and use CA glue on the seems. Seal inside joints with silicone.   
Assemble as seen in the sketchup file.  
The top piece in the sketchup file is cement board.  
Take apart a portable heater, or use a power supply and nichrome wire for the heating element. Any heating element will work. Use ceramic posts if possible to attach the heating wire to the cement board.  
Use a shopvac or vacuum pump (~3CFM) for the suction.

remixed_from.author: kutch
remixed_from.title: Fermentation Cap for Ball Canning Jars

description.text: This lid uses water to form an air trap that will let carbon dioxide and other gasses vent off of fermenting foods, while keeping out the oxygen that would spoil them. Some ideas for fermented foods this could be used for include sauerkraut, kimchi, ginger beer, or pickled vegetables (garlic, carrots, peppers, etc). Fermented foods are healthy, easy to prepare, and taste delicious. This was inspired by this: http://www.pickl-it.com/ and motivated by this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4663 and my completion of a general purpose canning jar lid (here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19105). The air trap is one piece, with no moving or meshing parts. This thing is a part of a collection of things featured in this post: http://www.protoparadigm.com/blog/2012/08/what-to-do-with-a-3d-printer-make-canning-jar-accessories/

This is a work in progress. At present, the air trap mechanism seems to work just fine, but the lid itself doesn't seal well enough to provide a barrier to gas. A gasket (a jar rubber or something) probably needs to be incorporated to keep the whole thing sealed. Parafin dripped around where this part and the jar make contact may do the trick. To print, you'll need to make sure it is as air-proof as possible. I'd recommend 100% infill. Make sure your bridging works reasonably well, and that your layers and traces flow together well. To use it, just put it on your jar, and fill the reservoir on top about half full of water. If you under-fill it, it won't do anything, and if you over-fill it you'll get water leaking down into your jar (though this shouldn't hurt the food, so it probably wouldn't be much of a problem). For some recipes for fermented foods, check out http://www.pickl-it.com/blog/recipes/ . Some of the recipes are a bit out there, but some of them are pretty standard, tasty fare. There are many other places to find recipes to find recipes too; I picked this one because the recipes are targeted towards small (canning jar sized) batches.

comments.text: One idea for making a better seal could be to design a version of this that is just the middle part and uses the existing jar ring to tighten it down maybe!
comments.author: ChaseSK88

comments.text: I've thought about making a version like that which would use the rubber gasket from Tattler canning lids ( https://www.amazon.com/Tattler-Reusable-Mouth-Canning-Rubber/dp/B0055PU5DC ). I've got some on-hand, but haven't had the time to give it a shot.

description.text: This is a jig to turn standard craft sticks (popsicle sticks) or jumbo craft sticks ( tongue depressors) into amusing propellers which you can attach to dowels to make hand-powered helicopters or pinwheels.

Printer:

FolgerTech Prusa 2020 i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed in natural PLA on glass. Bed at 75F, extruder at 220F. This is about a 3.5 hour print using a total of 88 g of plastic. Because of this print's size, ABS will tend to warp unless you take special precautions (e.g. an enclosure)

Making Propellers

This uses either standard craft sticks ( 113 mm x 9 mm x 1.5mm) or jumbo craft sticks ( 148mm x 17 mm x 1.5 mm) to make propellers.

Mark the center of your craft stick by putting it in the template slot in the bottom of the jig, then pushing a 6 penny finishing nail ( 2.6 mm x 63.8 mm) point first through the hole in the middle of the jig.

Boil your craft stick for about 30 minutes, making sure it is completely submerged in the water.

Put your stick through the slots in the top of the jig and let it dry overnight.

Nail the stick through your center mark to the top of a 5 mm dowel to make a helicopter. Drill a 1 mm hole through the center, thread the prop onto a nail and add a bead for a spacer, then nail that to a larger dowel to make a pinwheel.

Design

Designed with BRL-CAD, an open-source 3D CAD system developed in 1984. This software is clunky, but powerful and stable.

title: Ghostbusters Neutrino Wand aka Proton Gun
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Ghostbusters Neutrino Wand aka Proton Gun

“Who you gonna call? Ghostbusters!”

Designed to be as simple as possible, the Ghostbusters Neutrino Wand doesn’t need any special print settings or post print assembly. The idea was to make it one piece, but because of the size, it had to be divided in 4 pieces. Just glue them together and you’re ready to bust some ghosts! =)

It has detailed parts like buttons, knobs, wires and even welded parts to make it as real as possible, all 3d printed, making it “ready to use” prop. It still allows you to paint it afterwards if you want.

Enjoy!

title: Geared Tri-fidget spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE 1/23/17
Added an option for a flat finger cap, if you want this just print 2 of the flat finger cap stl's no need for a shoulder as they are a part of the cap.

Yet another fidget spinner. These use a 22mm skateboard bearing and the finger cap is designed for an id bearing of 8mm.
Theres a model for ABS and PLA
These are TIGHT, I suggest printing everything at 100% infill and using something flat to press the bearings in with. A vise works if you've got one, otherwise, I just use the handle of a hammer.
The shoulder/finger caps go together very tight as well, I like to use a pair of channel locks to snap them together
Enjoy.

comments.text: CRKT FTW!
comments.author: Mr_BadWrench

comments.text: I scaled mine up to 101% in my makerbot desktop and it fit with very little pressure. 100% cracked when I put the bearings in. If you want something with a bit more friction but no cracks (and want a normal infill) I would suggest scaling up to about 101% or 100.75% if it can do that)

title: Sense Scan and reverse engineer test, Bell & Howell WWII movie camera

description.text: I continue to experiment with my Sense scanner and inspired by someone's box camera scan, I decided to do my Dad's movie camera that he used in WWII.  I also wanted to experiment with reading glass lenses.  In the pics, the blue is the out of box scan.  I think it might have turned out better with better lighting.  The Purple is with a 2.5 reading glass lens.  It did a much better job with getting the overall shape but is not as sharp, which is odd.  I will try it again this weekend.  The one on the right is done with my  Rx glasses over the Sense...not. I pulled the scan into DesignSpark (a Spaceclaim derivative) and reverse engineered the overall size and shape and then added details by visually eyeballing things, no measurements.  It turned out pretty good. The scans and model are lifesize.  This camera was powered by winding it up.  My dad used it during his service in the US, England, France, Germany, and Austria during WWII.
I have not printed it yet, this has been a scan and modelling exercise so far.

comments.text: WORD OF CAUTION: if you remove lenses from reading glasses to use with the Sense scanner, be aware that the clear plastic that covers the lenses on the scanner can be easily scratched. This goes for general use of the Sense scanner also, be careful where and how you set it down.  When using lenses, I stretch electrical tape about the edges of the lens to cover the sharp edges and protect the Sense if the lenses are taped to it. If you make a holder for the lenses, it should eliminate the issue. However, when experimenting and taping lenses on, be careful.
comments.author: MakerBeck

comments.text: Some people have experimented with using reading glass lenses from the Pharmacy that sell real low cost.  Most have use +2.5 lenses which magnify things 2.5 times.  This has been done with the Microsoft Kinect for windows device with Recontstructme software and Skanect.  The lens is attached in front of the lens on the scanner to allow it to scan closer and get more detail.  I wanted to try the same thing with the Sense scanner to see if it helped to get detail on small objects.  I seen by my scans, it seems to help but not as much as I hope. I plan to experiment some more on lens placement.  In my first try, I just used masking tape to hold it in place over the lense, it may have been too close since your glasses are not that close to your real eyes.
comments.author: MakerBeck

comments.text: I noticed you said you used a RX len on the scanner, can you explain about that please.

Printable mouse trap for the Cathals Mouse Trap challenge. This mouse trap combines the both desires of the mouse; the love for exercise wheels and peanut butter (and ours for catching those buggers). Idea is simple. Trap spreads the aroma of the bait from the openings at the sides of the wheel.
The mouse then goes in to the wheel from the hole and in inside tries to reach the bait from the opposite side of the wheel.
Then the weight of the mouse turns the eccentric wheel and rotates it over 90 degrees, locking it in place and blocking the exit.
Weight of the mouse acts as a locking mechanism. Not yet tested but in my mind it works.
http://www.dailymotion.com/video/xcfwgj_exercise-wheel-mousetrap_animals UPDATE: In previous zip file, one file got corrupted at some point and did not work. This has been fixed now in the MouseTrap.zip -file. In the MouseTrapBPlat.zip are resized stl files that are for people who have build platfrom bolts still installed.
I don't know how these flaws got past me unnoticed and I apologize for the lack of quality control.
Big thanks to Cathal for bringing these to my attention. UPDATE #2: Lesson learned. Never know what to anticipate when you're not printing these yourself. Nothing big but the orientation for the other foot was wrong, too big to print that way. Fixed now in the mousetrap.zip UPDATE #3: Finally uploaded a video of this in action. Sorry for the wait :)
http://www.dailymotion.com/video/xfdi0y_better-mousetrap-challenge-test-vid_tech

Print all the .stl files from the .zip file
Clean
Assemble the wheel by matching the notches above and gluing it together.
Assemble the stand by gluing the supports to the legs.
Bait
Set
Wait Note: Largest part is 92mm x 70mm

title: Battleshots XL, a laser-cut drinking game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Plays just like Battleship, but you drink when your opponent hits you! This design requires 34 20x100mm test-tubes to hold the liquid. NOTE that I recommend scaling this down to 12x75mm tubes! I originally ordered those, but the seller shipped the wrong tubes so I scaled the whole thing up, hence the "XL". This design uses only cord to hold it together, no hardware, no adhesives.

Uprights: Whiteboard, 375x495mm, two pieces. (Or if you find something double-sided that takes dry-erase marker well, just use one and etch on both faces. I guess opaque white acrylic would work.)
Playfields: Translucent blue acrylic, 375x375mm, two pieces. I used wood and it was a bad idea, because wood swells up when you spill enough beer on it. I think ocean-blue would look great, especially if you add some artwork to jazz it up. Waves, perhaps?
Bottom layers: Opaque blue acrylic, 375x375mm, two pieces. These are identical in size to the playfields but featureless, aside from the mounting holes. Draw some sea-floor stuff on 'em (critters, shipwrecks) for style?
Fasteners: About 3m of thin cord, I used a "parachute cord" style material but much thinner, maybe 2mm diameter. It was fairly stretchy, which was annoying; aim for something stout and easy to tie. No other fasteners required.
Tubes: I got my test tubes cheap on Amazon. They sent the wrong ones. (Seller explains that he was on vacation and let his shipping guy pull the orders. Oops!) So, that's why this thing is so big, and is used with beer. The original concept was for much smaller tubes, appropriate for liquor. 
Files: I'm not sure if the different line types are obvious in the DXF files. I originally designed the whole thing in Leetro LaserCut 5.3, which sucks (it's totally NOT a cad package), but I was pressed for time and it's all I had. LaserCut can export DXF which Thingiverse seems to like, but if you want the original files, leave a comment and I'll upload those too. 
Cutting: On the playfield, etch the text, then cut the holes and the perimeter. On the uprights, etch the grid and the text, then cut the holes and the perimeter. On the bottom layers, simply cut the holes and the perimeter.
Assembly: Cut four short (~15cm) lengths of cord, and use them to tie the pieces together using the small holes inset from the edges. If this isn't obvious from the pics, please let me know and I'll make a diagram. Then, cut two long pieces of cord, and run them in an X from the corner of the bottom layer, through the playfield, up to the upright, then across the upright (crossing in the middle through the U-shaped cutout) and down through the other hole. Again, if this isn't obvious from the pics, please leave a comment and I'll explain it better. Tie knots to let the boards rest on the knots.
Note: In the photos, the marker grid on the uprights is the exact same scale as the hole grid in the playfield. This means that it extends down behind the tubes, and it's awkward to get your marker in there to record shots if you have tubes placed in the first few rows. I fixed this in the files that I've uploaded here, so the grid on the uprights is smaller and should provide adequate clearance.
Gameplay: It's just like the well-known Milton-Bradley Battleship game, but not suitable for kids! Drink when one of your ships gets hit. (Putting the tube back into the board, upside-down, is a good way to remember where your ships were as they start to get destroyed.) 
Gameplay modifications: Loser must consume any remaining tubes in the winner's fleet. Load one tube with a mystery shot. Some of my friends simply used the tubes as placeholders, and took a sip from their regular beer bottle when hit, a sensible modification for germophobes. 
For the foul-mouthed: It was noisy, so I was using phonetics (alfa, bravo, charlie, delta..) to call out my guesses. My opponent started making up his own (abortion, boobs, chlamydia, dingleberry...) and it kinda escalated from there. Coming up with a new word for every turn was harder than the whole rest of the game, slowed us down a lot, and made us laugh a lot harder. 
Just sayin: "Frigate" is an awesome word.

author: VicR

description.text:
A snowman Christmas ornament designed for 3D printing. Print the body and arms separate then glue the arms in place. I designed this in Fusion 360. After printing I applied a coat of primer and painted with acrylic paint. Check out video below to see my full process.

Learn to design with my free Fusion 360 Crash Course at https://www.desktopmakes.com/

Video of design here https://youtu.be/DyAZyendHjc

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/DyAZyendHjc" ></iframe>

comments.text:
Hello!
VERY nice snowman! Very cheerfull and friendly looking!
comments.author: The_Monstro

comments.text: One small problem while printing with no infill.  When it gets up to the point of the holes for the stick arms, the nozzle starts printing in mid air for one of them.  This causes some blobs to get wiped onto the sides.  I'd rather not use infill to keep it as light as possible.
comments.author: xeddog

comments.text:
I follow you on fusion 360 tutorials and as I have seen your work is nothing but superb.
This snowman is so easy to print!!
Have you ever gave any thought to a santa claus a reindeer and an elves? I know there are some on thingiverse but none with the ease of printing as this
comments.author: oldfarmhand

comments.text: This model is very nice and a pleasure to print. Thank you for posting this.
comments.author: GiddyupHorsie

comments.text: Fantastic model snowman! I re-scaled and printed to 21cm height at 0.2 res, turned out great with no issues - will paint up it over the next few weekends and post a make :)

title: Mine cart for Minecraft toy figures

description.text:
This mine cart is scaled to fit the toy Minecraft toys being sold in stores.
I will be adding tracks and wheel soon.
I have two sets of wheels.
One with no axle and the other with.
This saves time if you have a rod or something to use as an axle.
I wonder if I could make this use the wheels from a HO scale train car.
If I can find some wheels to try I will make one that uses those wheel and then the cart could use HO scale train track.
Plus the wheels would roll very well.
Let me know what you want made next!

I printed mine upside down, but the bottom didn't print right.
I will be updating it to print better. (done, but not tested)
Steve fits in the cart very well.
The holes for the axle need to be larger and stronger.
This is not finished yet, but if you are using wheels from a HO scale train car, then this should work already.
The updated Minecart should work better.
Not sure why the wheels don't show. they slice fine and should print ok.
I may make them larger.
The newest Minecart STL will print right side up with no supports.
The tracks in the photos came from someones toy train tracks so I listed them as a source.

comments.text: cool,it looks like its made of paper clips,is it?
comments.author: mkx

comments.text: It is 3d printed using ABS plastic and painted silver with model paint.
comments.author: mkx

comments.text: sheep in the background, perhaps a tested future product?
comments.author: The3DPrintist

comments.text:
Someone already has that on thingiverse.
I just printed one. I could scale it to the Minecraft figures to make it easier for everyone.
comments.author: The3DPrintist

comments.text: oh, ok cool.
comments.author: mcsdaver

comments.text: the only problem i see in the mine craft track is that the track doesn't turn like in the game, its not tight enough.
comments.author: The3DPrintist

comments.text:
I am looking for better wheels and track as these wheels wont roll very well.
I think that HO scale train car wheels will fit my mine cart and make it roll on HO track.
I may still print the track, but I think the train car wheels are the right way to go to get the mine cart rolling.
The track I printed if from Sconine's toy train.http://http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11101www.thingiverse.com/thing:1110...
I will be making my own and they will turn 90 deg if I can keep the cart on the track.
If you print my Minecraft Tree you can paint the blocks how ever you want and use them as stone, dirt, or any block in the game. You can even make a portal if you print enough blocks.

comments.text: i tried to make them as close to minecraft accurate as possible, while keeping the cart to roll well. The track will fit snugly between blocks because it is the same sise of the normal blocks. The tracks fit together like those old Tomas toys but it looks better.

Glad you got some tracks made.

My 3d printer was close to $700.
The newer printers out now can print just as good and cost around $500.

comments.text: awesome do you recommend any close to $500 printers that print in the good filament you talked about in the message (I forgot if you said abs or pla was better)
comments.author: mcsdaver

comments.text:
I haven't tested any $500 dollar printers, so it is hard to recommend one.
Just search online and read up on them.
Many people like PLA better than ABS.
I have only used ABS and I know people who like ABS better.
I am not sure which is better.
Larger items ABS might be better and smaller ones PLA might.
I need to get a printer that uses PLA.

remixed_from.title: MacBook Pro Retina / Air 13 inch - Dock

description.text:
I was re-created in OpenSCAD 3D models. It is possible to change the thickness of the MacBook you have because it can be adjusted in the slot spacing. It takes much longer when you run it "(F6) Compile and Render" because it uses, "minkowski" command, however. (6-24 hours)
  • the display is the highest speed that is set to "0" parameter of "edge_r" is when you want to preview. ("fn $ = 16/32" also change the speed up)
    • [macbook_holder_v4_215.stl] => slot spacing 21.5mm
    [macbook_holder_v4_265.stl] => slot spacing 26.5mm

remixed_from.author: MartinMajewski
remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 MK2(s) & MK3 Spool Holder - Frame Mount - Top Loader

title: Support Arms for Spool Holder for Prusa i3 MK2 - Hex Design -

description.text:
I found the original Support arms for, MartinMajewski's Spool Holder for Prusa i3 MK2 - Hex Design, tended to wobble and walk side to side when trying to set a filament spool on them. So I remixed them to have a 10mm wide frame clip to hopefully prevent that.

Update #1 - So I finally got these printed and tested and they help a lot with the wobble issue, how ever they don't remove it completely, to do that I would have to add support to the inside of the arms making them harder to print.

I've provided multiple version here with 10mm or 15mm support and with or with out a chamfer edge on the extended support.

author: Seb200

title: Adjustable Smartphone Holder for FrSky Taranis X9D
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is smartphone holder that mounts to the handle on the back of the Taranis transmitter. The clasp that holds the phone from the top is adjustable for different size phones. Once adjusted to the appropriate size, the clasp is flexible enough to easily allow the phone to be removed and replaced while still holding it securely. I printed in PETG and it has just the right amount of flex where it is needed. With PLA that may not be the case.

It is designed to be printed in three pieces with no support required (when using the proper orientation). The only other items required for assembly are 4 M3 screws. I also cut a small piece of thin, rubbery shelf mat material and placed it between the mounting block and the main assembly to give it a bit firmer grip on the handle without necessarily having to crank down very hard on the screws that secure it.

comments.text: Nice mod! I printed and I am going to use it, for sure. The major thing I will think how to improve is the fact it rolls where it is attached to the Taranis handle, although the antenna stops the movement a bit.
comments.author: cartolla

comments.text: Glad you are able to make use of it.  One thing that might help is to make the triangular block that straddles the bar out of TPE or even TPU.  This, combined with tightening down on the screws really hard, made mine fit firmly in place.
comments.author: cartolla

comments.text: I like this design, I even extended the arm to incorporate an iPad (For DJI Ground Station eventually!) but it's too heavy and leans back and I can't figure out another way to clamp it!
comments.author: ChrisMayhew

comments.text: Glad you like the design.  I did not envision something as large as an iPad when I pieced this together.  You might try altering it so that there are two arms and arm tracks instead of just the one set, beef them up and space them out a little.  Good luck.  Hope you find something the suits your needs.
comments.author: ChrisMayhew

comments.text: Thanks.. I'm working on modding it so that it will accommodate an iPad hopefully :)

This custom designed "IR_POD" is meant to hold 2 infrared LEDs and 1 infrared detector snugly as to ease the testing and later prototyping of a project im currently working on.

The 2 round holes can hold most common sized LEDs and the rectangle in the middle is for holding a TSOP IR detector.

The dimensions allow the IR LEDs light rays to be focused foward and outward and allows the IR detector to be sheilded from any outside rays of light. However the pod can be used for many other small projects involving any type of LEDs.

INSTALLATION :

The front of the pod is identified by having a completly flat surface.

The back of the pod is identified by having small chamfers(indents) of about 0.2mm for the LEDs and 0.2mm-0.3mm for the detector which is also recessed a bit.

Insert LEDs top first from the back and the detector face first from the back of the pod.(you may need to remove metal case that most TSOP IR detectors have)

You may want to use a small amount of glue to keep the detector snug only after you have soldered and tested your pod with the new IR LEDs and TSOP detector.

thats it!!! good luck tinkering!!!

For those who are still pondering what the hell an IR_POD is i have created this illustration that shows just how the pod works once you install your infrareds and detector.

Thank you for checking out my custom designs!!

PLEASE LEAVE A SMALL TIP IF YOU USE THIS, better yet!! leave an idea for a custom design and ill make it reality ;)

happy tipping

title: FASTER fidget spinner for people with short fingers (v2)

description.text:
Yet another fidget spinner, only faster! As a guy with short fingers, available spinners were not so good to everyday use. Also, there were few asymmetrical options, which I prefer. My first try on this was very good (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1846220), but I found it a little too slow after some time. Then, I came up with this new design, Hope you all like it.

Use 22mm ballbearings (number 608)

Better with the caps (make them colorful)

no need for supports

50% infill. ABS or PLA, it doesn't matter

Please, share it if you print it.
If you print in ABS, sand the pieces and cover them with CA glue. They'll shine beautifully.
Fusion360 from Autodesk

title: Ink Bottle Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you've ever gotten frustrated when trying to fill your fountain pens from a bottle of Noodler's Ink which isn't very full any more, you're not alone. This little holder will securely hold a Noodler's (or other 41.5mm rounded square profile) bottle securely at a 45 degree angle, to help you get the ink out of the bottle and into your pen where it belongs. Also makes a handy inkwell in company with a de-labeled bottle.

I strongly recommend printing the monogram section slowly and/or creating extra supports if needed. I printed this with full supports, but as the monogram section is at only 45deg. to the build plate, most slicers won't create any for it and letters with large internal sections left hanging will get dicey pretty quickly.

If you wish to change the monogramming, just edit the included OpenSCAD code and re-render. Hope you enjoy.

title: Parametric Prusa Lower Z Axis Mount

description.text: As my z axis motor couplings tends to slip regularly, I needed a lower z axis mount, but for 6mm threaded/smooth rods, so I took the original design, and recreated it (or a close enough version) in openscad. Hope it can be usefull!

The inluded stl is just for reference, 6mm threaded and smooth rods, 25 mm between z axis threaded and smooth rods, 25 mm between z axis threaded rod and the lower "square" threaded rod.
Will add more details on parametric setting in a bit (but should be relatively clear already with the comments in the openscad file).

description.text:
A complete rewrite of my customizable hinge! The new version is immensely more printable and quite possibly over parameterized. No longer do you need to break it free, as long as the hinge gap parameter is set to something your printer can handle it should hinge easily right off of the bed!

Major changes from the old version include using angled interfaces between the hinge points instead of a solid pin to provide improved printability and much more flexibility for the screw holes.

Update 2016-12-12 - The hinge can no longer overlap the leafs when it's small, or the leafs are too thick. Also modified the balanced screwhole spacing to place closer to the edges.

Overview

This thing presents Scalar XL Premium 3D printer.

Scalar Family 3D printers are "scalable" printers.

This version is a fully upgraded version of the original Scalar XL model ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:891409 )

Reviewing the idea of a reprap printer, a printer that can auto replicate and scale, we wanted to propose a 3D printer with plastic parts for you to print, and with a way to "scale" easily.

Key Features

  • More stability and Accuracy with
    Bed with Dual drive system ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1766326 )
    Z Axis based on Strong Jaw System ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1912785 )
  • Possible upgrade to Helix drive system ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1912399 )
  • More secure with our new SSR cover system ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1912871)
  • Evolutive Design : More upgrades are to come!
  • Strong with 3030 aluminium extrusion
  • Smooth and Silent: using VSlots and V Wheels for X and Y axis

Assembly instructions

Assembly instructions can be found on our website documentation page:
http://doc.3dmodularsystems.com/scalar-lxl-premium-assembly-manual/

Updates

  • 2018.03.05 - Update BasicHolderFor2020V3 and 2020_X_Idler_TensionerV5 (stronger)
  • 2017.12.20 - Added X axis end stop with screws (M2.5X8mm) => 2020_X_EndStop_Holder_screw.stl
  • 2017.08.16 - Re-inforced X axis Idler tensioner
  • 2017.08.03 - Updated list of list to upgrades
  • 2017.06.30 : Fix X Carriage
  • 2016.12.01 : Original release

Remixed

This thing is a remix from our original version:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:891409
Many of you liked it.
The main idea remains, but we adjusted the overall size to something more standard, and we reviewed/remodelled all the plastic parts to:

  • Have a better design
  • Have stronger parts.
  • Reduce noise
  • Increase Z axis Accuracy
  • Increase X axis smooth motion
  • Upgrade heat bed motion system
  • Designed a box for the electronics
  • remove Belt tensioner
  • Stronger Spool Holder

Printer presentation

https://youtu.be/AtUzb07cCs4

Firmware

The procedure to install the firmware on Scalar 3D printer is available on our documentation page:
http://doc.3dmodularsystems.com/updatingupgrading-your-3d-printer-firmware/

You will also find the newest firmware available to download directly on the page.
Special thanks to Marlin Community for providing this great firmware and evolutions.

Misc

  • Calibration set: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:909829

Where to buy

http://3dmodularsystems.com/en/3d-printers/207-scalar-xl-premium-3d-printer-large-volume-pre-assembled-kit.html

Characteristics

Mainly all technical information can be found on our website:
http://3dmodularsystems.com

But here is a summary of the main characteristics :

Scalar XL Premium

  • XL build platform: 400x300mm heat-bed
  • 220V 700w silicon heat-bed with a 3mm aluminium print surface
  • Compatible with well known hot ends (E3D, Hexagone, ...), 3mm and 1.75mm
  • Built-in blower fan
  • Built-in LCD and SD card support
  • Built-in spool holder
  • 200W 12V industrial power supply
  • Inductive probe for bed levelling
  • Plastic parts available for different hot ends: E3D, AluHotEnd and Prometheus V1.1.
  • Modular Design

Scalability

Because you guys have different ways of life, events happening and so on, we wanted to make sure that those printers can be scaled by only adding the necessary parts to upgrade/downgrade your printers.
This way whenever you want the printer to be bigger then we have a kit for that:
We already made several Upgrade kits for our previous Scalar XL model and we plan to keep the "Scalable" / Evolutivity concept for this model! So be prepare, there is plenty of cool stuff to come.

BOM

Available on our documentation page http://doc.3dmodularsystems.com/scalar-lxl-premium-assembly-manual/

3D Modular Systems
Evolutive 3D Printers

title: Olaf Snowman maker (Remix)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My second entry for the #RemixChallenge. My daughter loves Frozen, so naturally, we should have an Olaf snowman maker!

Extra Credit Opportunity! Place drops of food coloring into the mold where his nose, eyes, buttons, and arms are for a full color Olaf!

Feb 1st, 2018 - Changed the body of the mold to a snowperson shape, which should cut down the volume, which should save material. I also changed the cylinder pegs to half spheres, which should cut down on the chance of them breaking when trying to separate the mold. I haven't test printed it yet, but I'll upload photos when I do.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm or better

Notes:

Should print with 0.1mm layer height or better to allow a high level of detail to appear!

I printed the 'box' one in the picture on a MakerBot Mini, and it's just short of 100mm tall. Nice level of detail, but the arms/hands don't look like they'll come out well on a snowman. Would definitely scale up for a usable one!

I scaled this up and I don't believe the arms will come out well either way. Just use sticks!

Subtracting and separating with TinkerCAD and Slic3r!

When I saw the snowman maker on the #RemixChallenge collection and I knew I had to remix Olaf. I found an Olaf mold by rocketboy already on thingiverse, but I also want to show the steps I used to create this snowman maker, in case someone else wants to learn.

Step 1 - Check the Model

First thing I did was find a model of Olaf I thought would work well. embeddedjunkie's model look like it would work well if split right down the middle, so I picked that one. By coincidence, it's the same model the rocketboy used to make his mold! I imported the .stl of embeddedjunkie's Olaf into TinkerCAD to see if any mesh errors come up. Nothing major appeared!

I'm a happy snowman! Step 2 - The Block

Second thing I did was I raised the model 5mm off the floor of the workspace, this part is important so that the feet of the model don't stick out of the bottom of the snowman maker! Then I added a simple cube to my workspace which would become the snowman maker. Don't forget to apply the 'hole' setting to the Olaf model, that way the model gets 'removed' from our cube! I stretched the X and Y axis of the cube to make sure it would extend over all the details by at least 5mm, that way there wouldn't be any holes extending from where the snow goes and the outside of the snowman maker. This is also why we raised the model 5mm at the beginning! Use the picture below as a reference.

Notice that the cube extends at least 5mm farther than any features. Step 3 - Paper Cut

Third thing I did was create another cube which I stretched as wide as my snowman maker was, and as tall as the snowman maker was. Then I made it only 0.1mm thick. Imagine this is a piece a paper, and it represents the 'cut' that will split our model into two pieces! Position the 'paper' so that it splits the model into as equal parts as you can get. Use the picture below as a reference.

The yellow 'paper' piece splits the model in half! Step 4 - 'The Trick'

There has to be a trick, if you want these all grouped together nicely. First, select the Olaf model and make him about 10mm taller(stretch him 10mm taller along the Z axis). Then make the snowman maker(the red cube) 5mm shorter than the Olaf model. Then select the Olaf model and shrink him back down to original size(10mm shorter along the Z axis). The Olaf model should still be selected, even though it's now hidden inside the red cube. Make sure that you Shift-Click to select the red cube along with the Olaf model that should already be selected, and group them together. This trick should 'remove' the OIaf model from the inside of the red cube.

Step 5 - Cut in Half

Now it should look like you have a big red cube with 'paper' piece slicing through the middle. Selected the 'paper' piece and make it a 'hole.' Select the 'paper' hole and the red cube and group them together. This effectively cuts your model in half. Use the picture below as a reference.

Snowman Maker after the 'paper' hole grouping. Step 6 - Separation

TinkerCAD won't easily seperate these two pieces, but Slic3r will! So export your file from TinkerCAD and open it up in Slic3r! For reference, I'm running version 1.2.9 of Slic3r. Once you have it open in Slic3r, hit the 'Split' button in the toolbar and BAM! you've got both sides split. All you have to do now is rotate them so the relief is facing up and print!

Do the splits!

title: STAR WARS DC-15s Blaster Rifle (Last Version)

description.text:
New 3.0 version ! (2017/01/21)

3D printable edition of the famous Star Wars DC-15s clone's blaster !

At the request of many people I published for you a new version ;
What's New : now 23 PARTS instead of 11 only, correctly cuted in order to print the blaster very easily ! The design has been improved, and all dimensions have been corrected (66cm long instead of 41cm).

SPECS :

  • Model originaly designed on SolidWorks 2010, and recently reissued on SolidWorks 2016.
  • 23 defferent part, 28 parts in total.
  • Largest part dimensions : 185 x 44 x 33 mm
  • Smallest part dimensions : 23.91 x 16.10 x 8.04 mm
  • Complete rifle dimensions (when all parts assembled) : 657.14 x 215.02 x 118.71 mm
  • Total lenght : 66 cm = 26 inches
  • Folding stock

Find all detailed specs in downloadable file " SPECS_01.21.2017 "

I'm currently printing this blaster, I'll go back to you soon !

  • Realistic renders created by PhotoView360' (V. 2010).

Thanks to like, comment & share this model to support me !
Feel free to comment this thing to say me if you like it or not, or if you have questions or suggestions !

  • Don't forget to share your making ! =D

Commercial version available ; just send me a donation ($7), I'll send you the complete (non text-engraved and multi-format) version !
(thanks to let me know it by message on thingiverse if interested)

Les français, n'hésitez pas à commenter je pourrai vous répondre ! ;D

Enjoy ;)

  Design Version : V_3.0 (Last Build - 2017/01)
  Print Version : V_3.0

Old version (2.1) available here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2052378

comments.author: Hikuro1983

comments.text:
It's more of the authentication of the prop that was printed. The 501st members I've encountered at conventions are very strict to only allowing people in their ranks with screen accurate costumes and items. I remember walking around in a sell made Jedi costume last year and they felt obligated to let me know that not only was my attire unacceptable to their standards, they weren't to thrilled with my Saberforge made light saber based on the old republic games cause they did some details differently for trademark.
Mostly why a lot of people who do 3D models for printing are asked if their work had been certified 501st or not.

print_settings.Notes:: on my home made MDF Delta printer, 608zz bearing fits in perfectly. I push the bearings in with my thumb and friction holds them in place. No glue. your printer may differ. The design has the bearing hole(s) at exactly 22 mm (r=11).

description.text:
my take of a fidget spinner. two models, either use one 608 bearing or three 608 bearings. I find bearings spin better if soaked in WD-40 for 48 hours to remove the thick grease. then wash with hot soapy water to remove WD-40.

40% fill on the one bearing model. Less infill for the 3 bearing model.

Printer:

homemade 3D Delta

comments.text: Do you know a guide on how to wire the display?
comments.author: Gremble

comments.text:
I hope you know something about the hardware stuffs. The LCD is a ILI9341 base LCD panel with SPI interface. You should wire up the following LCD pin correctly to the pi:
DC, CS, SCLK, MOSI and RESET pin.
You can google search "ILI9341" and "raspberry pi" for more information.
comments.author: Gremble

title: Small Watering Can
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Also featured - slightly scaled up - by Angus in Maker's Muse on YouTube..

I needed a small watering can for the office, so I designed one after my fancy. I decided to make it a vase, because I just love those seamless surfaces and I had an idea how to incorporate a rigid grip (that worked very well).

It holds up to about 150 ml, which should be plenty for my good old Zamioculcas, Bonsai, cacti or other succulents.

Of course you can use it as a coffee milk jug as well, just please take care to print with a food safe material then.

I'd love to see your Make! :)

Printer:

Malyan M200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Notes:

These are the settings for the white version in my pics.
Extrudr BDP Green-Tec white (biodegradable)
215°/40° on BuildTak
40 mm/s
0.4 nozzle
3 concentric bottom layers
single outline corkscrew printing mode (vase mode)
about 1 hour print time

With an extrusion width of about 0.5 mm, the walls overlap in one spot to stabilize the handle, adding a lot to the overall rigidity of the print.

comments.text: When set to vase mode, Cura creates a hole in the middle of the handle portion of the model. Is there something I am doing wrong? It seems that the only way to fix it is by scaling the part up. Please let me know if this is fixable.
comments.author: Gabgra11

comments.text:
I'm sorry, I never had this with Simplify3D. Did you use the full-volume model? The others won't work for vase mode.
That spot in the handle does have the walls (supposing they are about 0.5 mm wide) overlap for some tenths of a mm so they fuse together and stabilize the handle. I've never used Cura, but I suppose there should be a setting to fix this problem. From what I can find online, I would try one setting at a time in this order and see if the sliced preview looks any better:
comments.author: Gabgra11

comments.text:
Hello, I am using the full volume model in vase mode. I am using a pretty old version of Cura, so I will try with the newer version. Thanks for the help! If it doesn't work, I might just scale it up and try again. I don't really mind if there is a gap between the walls of the handle, as long as it is water tight.
Thanks again!
comments.author: shmeeed

comments.text: I printed this thing in vase mode in a semi clear white PLA, and it came out I'd say, perfect.  It's almost like a frosted transparent look, no leaks.
comments.author: cnorth

comments.text: Why is the top concealed? Can you up load one with out this
comments.author: benmccabe19

comments.text:
I did now, but that’s kind of missing the point of a vase object.
What slicer are you using? There should be a function to hollow out objects, called “vase mode” or “single outline corkscrew printing mode” (Simplify3D), meaning it prints in a continuous spiral from the bottom layers to the top without interrupting. You also have to set your top layers to zero for that to work.
